anime_techniques.name: Limited animation (TV production)
anime_techniques.explain: Uses fewer frames and strategic holds/cycles to reduce drawing load while maintaining clarity and timing.

anime_techniques.name: Key animation + in-betweening
anime_techniques.explain: Key animators define major poses; in-between drawings create smooth motion between keys.

anime_techniques.name: Layout + timing sheets
anime_techniques.explain: Shot planning that specifies camera/framing and frame-by-frame timing for motion and effects.

cartoon_techniques.name: Cel animation
cartoon_techniques.explain: Characters are drawn on transparent sheets and layered over a fixed background; separates moving parts from the background.

cartoon_techniques.name: Stop-motion
cartoon_techniques.explain: Physical models are moved incrementally and photographed frame-by-frame to create motion.

cartoon_techniques.name: Cut-out animation
cartoon_techniques.explain: Flat pieces are moved frame-by-frame (paper/digital equivalents) to animate characters and scenes.

traditional_tools.use: Standardized paper aligned with pegs to keep drawings consistent across frames.
Illuminated surface used to trace, refine, and register in-between drawings.
Hardware that locks paper in place so drawings align consistently.
Non-photo pencils for rough passes; graphite for clean-up lines.
Traditional workflow: ink lines and paint fills on cels (historically common in studios).
